cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology. Difficult Terrain is a universal movement rule applicable across all planes and environments where terrain impedes movement.

planeCategories.name: Material Realm
planeCategories.description: Worlds of the Material Plane where Difficult Terrain most commonly applies in combat and exploration contexts.

planes.name: Difficult Terrain

hazards.name: Difficult Terrain
hazards.description: If a space is Difficult Terrain, every foot of movement in that space costs 1 extra foot, even if multiple things in a space count as Difficult Terrain. Examples include low furniture, rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, and shallow bogs.
hazards.sourceReference: Chapter 1: Playing the Game, Combat > Movement and Position > Difficult Terrain; Appendix C: Rules Glossary > Difficult Terrain

hazards.name: Another Creature's Space as Difficult Terrain
hazards.description: Another creature's space is Difficult Terrain for you unless that creature is Tiny or your ally. You can pass through the space of an ally, a creature that has the Incapacitated condition, a Tiny creature, or a creature that is two sizes larger or smaller than you. You can't willingly end a move in a space occupied by another creature.
hazards.sourceReference: Chapter 1: Playing the Game, Combat > Movement and Position > Moving Around Other Creatures

hazards.name: Climbing in Difficult Terrain
hazards.description: While climbing, each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot (2 extra feet in Difficult Terrain). At the DM's option, climbing a slippery surface requires a successful DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check.

interactionCheck.name: Climbing Slippery Surface
interactionCheck.description: At the DM's option, climbing a slippery surface requires a successful DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check.

onFailure.description: The creature fails to make progress climbing the slippery surface.

hazards.name: Crawling in Difficult Terrain
hazards.description: While crawling, each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot (2 extra feet in Difficult Terrain).

hazards.name: Swimming in Difficult Terrain
hazards.description: While swimming, each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot (2 extra feet in Difficult Terrain) unless a creature has a Swim Speed.

hazards.name: Landing in Difficult Terrain after a Jump
hazards.description: If you land in Difficult Terrain, you must make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or have the Prone condition.

interactionCheck.name: Landing in Difficult Terrain
interactionCheck.description: When you land in Difficult Terrain after a jump, you must make a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or have the Prone condition.

onSuccess.description: You land safely without falling Prone.

hazards.name: Difficult Terrain on a Grid
hazards.description: When playing on a square grid, a square of Difficult Terrain costs 2 squares to enter (equivalent to 10 feet of movement per 5-foot square). Entering an unoccupied non-Difficult Terrain square costs 1 square of movement.
hazards.sourceReference: Chapter 1: Playing the Game, Combat > Movement and Position > Playing on a Grid sidebar

environmentalEffects.name: Difficult Terrain Does Not Stack
environmentalEffects.description: Every foot of movement in Difficult Terrain costs 1 extra foot, even if multiple things in a space count as Difficult Terrain. Multiple sources of Difficult Terrain in the same space do not compound; the extra cost remains 1 extra foot per foot moved.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Movement cost in Difficult Terrain is always 2 feet per 1 foot of actual movement regardless of the number of overlapping Difficult Terrain sources. On a grid, each square of Difficult Terrain costs 2 squares to enter.
environmentalEffects.sourceReference: Chapter 1: Playing the Game, Combat > Movement and Position > Difficult Terrain

environmentalEffects.name: Other Effects May Increase Square Entry Cost
environmentalEffects.description: While the base Difficult Terrain rule states 1 extra foot per foot of movement, other effects might make a square cost even more. The grid sidebar notes: 'Other effects might make a square cost even more.' This allows specific features, spells, or environmental effects to exceed the standard Difficult Terrain movement penalty.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Specific game effects can increase the cost to enter a square beyond the standard 2 squares for Difficult Terrain. These are distinct from Difficult Terrain stacking and represent additional rule layers.
environmentalEffects.sourceReference: Chapter 1: Playing the Game, Combat > Movement and Position > Playing on a Grid sidebar

environmentalEffects.name: Common Examples of Difficult Terrain
environmentalEffects.description: Low furniture, rubble, undergrowth, steep stairs, snow, and shallow bogs are examples of Difficult Terrain. Another creature's space (unless Tiny or allied) also counts as Difficult Terrain.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Any space containing these environmental features is treated as Difficult Terrain, costing 1 extra foot of movement per foot traveled.
environmentalEffects.sourceReference: Chapter 1: Playing the Game, Combat > Movement and Position > Difficult Terrain

specialRules.name: Difficult Terrain Interaction with Climbing
specialRules.description: Climbing already costs 1 extra foot per foot of movement. In Difficult Terrain, climbing costs 2 extra feet per foot of movement instead (total of 3 feet of movement per 1 foot climbed).
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Base climbing cost: 2 feet of movement per 1 foot climbed. Climbing in Difficult Terrain: 3 feet of movement per 1 foot climbed.

specialRules.name: Difficult Terrain Interaction with Crawling
specialRules.description: Crawling already costs 1 extra foot per foot of movement. In Difficult Terrain, crawling costs 2 extra feet per foot of movement instead (total of 3 feet of movement per 1 foot crawled).
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Base crawling cost: 2 feet of movement per 1 foot crawled. Crawling in Difficult Terrain: 3 feet of movement per 1 foot crawled.

specialRules.name: Difficult Terrain Interaction with Swimming
specialRules.description: Swimming without a Swim Speed costs 1 extra foot per foot of movement. In Difficult Terrain, swimming costs 2 extra feet per foot of movement (total of 3 feet of movement per 1 foot swum). Creatures with a Swim Speed are not subject to the extra swimming cost but are still subject to Difficult Terrain's extra cost.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Base swimming cost without Swim Speed: 2 feet per 1 foot swum. Swimming in Difficult Terrain without Swim Speed: 3 feet per 1 foot swum. With Swim Speed in Difficult Terrain: 2 feet per 1 foot swum.

specialRules.name: Prone on Landing in Difficult Terrain
specialRules.description: When a creature jumps and lands in Difficult Terrain, it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or have the Prone condition. This applies to both Long Jumps and High Jumps.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check on landing in Difficult Terrain; failure results in the Prone condition.

specialRules.name: Creature Space as Difficult Terrain
specialRules.description: Another creature's space is Difficult Terrain for you unless that creature is Tiny or your ally. You can pass through the space of an ally, a creature with the Incapacitated condition, a Tiny creature, or a creature two sizes larger or smaller than you. You cannot willingly end your move in a space occupied by another creature. If you somehow end a turn in a space with another creature, you have the Prone condition unless you are Tiny or of a larger size than the other creature.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Non-allied, non-Tiny creature spaces cost 1 extra foot of movement to traverse. Ending a turn in an occupied space imposes the Prone condition (with size exceptions).

specialRules.name: Grid-Based Difficult Terrain Entry Cost
specialRules.description: On a square grid where each square represents 5 feet, entering a square of Difficult Terrain costs 2 squares of movement instead of the normal 1 square. Speed is translated to squares by dividing by 5 (e.g., Speed 30 = 6 squares).
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Each Difficult Terrain square costs 2 squares (10 feet equivalent) to enter on a grid. Normal squares cost 1 square (5 feet) to enter.
